heading: 1 Introduction
text: Cockburn Sound Western Australia unique coastal ecosystem renowned important economic environmental values, whilst also stress range anthropogenic activities climate change impacts. Deleterious water quality conditions feature system past severely impacted upon important ecosystem values, including seagrass benthic community health, pelagic fisheries, potentially also apex predators iconic species. historically poor water quality improving past decades due nutrient source control, however, past nutrient enrichment left legacy within system issues hypoxia, harmful algae, lack water clarity continue challenge managers negatively impact upon range users system (BMT, 2018). , concerns risks associated hypoxia, harmful algal blooms excessive turbidity may worsen future actively managed.part WAMSI Westport Marine Science Program (WWMSP), Cockburn Sound Integrated Ecosystem Model (hereafter referred ‘CSIEM’) developed tool quantify water quality habitat changes within ecosystem response different environmental conditions, assist allowing integrated assessment management scenarios, questions relevant decision-making. particular, model developed allow stakeholders move towards holistic cumulative assessment environmental risks, particularly motivated since recent updates Environmental Protection Amendment Act (2020) State Government Western Australia.building model intent develop ecosystem model able support multi-scale prediction needs development proponents environmental regulators seeking optimise ecosystem use, whilst capturing latest scientific findings data WWMSP research projects.core platform 3D hydrodynamic-ecological model, termed Cockburn Sound Integrated Ecosystem Model (CSIEM), nested within regional met-ocean predictions integrated variety environmental models. CSIEM developed part Project 1.2 WWMSP undertake hindcast forecast (scenario) predictions water mixing transport, salinity (S), temperature (T), aquatic biogeochemistry ecology. model implemented part overarching integrated platform designed coordinate inter-dependencies various modelling tools outputs model-data workflows, order provide holistic view environmental conditions Cockburn Sound.Initial phases CSIEM development focused model setup testing, included interim releases (intial versions including v0.9, v1.0, v1.1 v1.5). document provides “living-manual” model, giving overview technical guide model design capability data synthesis WWMSP research data findings occurs.

heading: 2 CSIEM Model Overview
text: CSIEM spatially resolved 3-dimensional (3D) model able simulate environmental conditions within Cockburn Sound adjacent areas within Perth Waters, spanning Quinns Rocks Mandurah. depth gradient spans shallow littoral waters approximately 20 meters centre Sound, context interactions ocean dynamics, catchment inputs, variable climate forcing, creates spectrum water quality conditions habitat distributions. capture spatio-temporal dynamics system, CSIEM designed bring together system environmental models able sequentially “downscale” global regional local, “vertically integrate” physical, chemical biological processes (Figure 2.1).core, model platform consists hydrodynamic model TUFLOW-FV water quality model AED. Different model domain resolutions can selected /time-periods interest simulated. Different levels model complexity also configurable user (e.g., enabling various biogeochemical ecological components modules), common input files output analysis workflows.model platform setup allow variety stakeholder needs use-cases providing allows common approach setup, configuration visualisation; example, long-term low-resolution habitat restoration simulation can run alongside high-resolution dredging scenario, simulations sharing common model settings, parameters, parameterisations. intent provide decision-makers single trusted tool can used answer diversity questions span day--day management long-term policy settings (e.g, restoration climate change adaptation strategies).general, models configured resolve hydrodynamics flushing, water temperature salinity, numerous water quality attributes including oxygen, nutrients (organic inorganic), planktonic organisms, seagrass benthic communities, suspended sediment. CSIEM also links large volume data historical surveys, real-time data streams recent experimental work. heading: 4.3.2 CSIEM TUFLOW-FV-AED model file organisation
text: TUFLOW-FV-AED model main modelling platform WWMSP project contains following folder structure:BCs: boundary condition files, including tide inflow boundary files; meteorological boundary files, initial condition files;External: AED model files linked TUFLOW-FV, optionally ‘GOTM’ vertical mixing model CSIEM 3D mode;Geo: TUFLOW-FV model structure files, including geometry mesh files, GIS files controlling nodestrings material zones;Input: model control/configuration files;Plotting : Directory store model output images;WINDOWS users model folder also contains bin directory containing compatible binaries TFV-AED modelTFV: Build version: 2020.03.105AED: Build version: 2.0.5b

heading: 5.1 Overview
text: Given inherently multi-scale nature coastal environments, numerical models CSIEM rely readily available large-scale ocean climatological data initialization, data assimilation, boundary forcing (Levitus, 1982; Kim et al., 2007). approach crucial identifying accounting external anomalies, sea level variations, marine heatwaves, nutrient anomalies, can influence even dominate local conditions. Researchers, therefore, create climatology improve parameterization specification hydrographic biogeochemical boundary conditions.Developing climatology Perth waters involves building temporal averages /statistical properties environmental variables characterize physical biochemical states ocean (Fukumori et al., 2018; Shahzadi et al., 2021). Oceanographers commonly generate monthly climatologies, scale global ocean (Levitus, 1982; Fukumori et al., 2018; Shahzadi et al., 2021) regional systems like Northwest Atlantic Ocean (Seidov et al., 2018), Central California (Kim et al., 2007), East Asian Seas (Johnson et al., 2015). climatologies typically developed objective analysis irregularly distributed data, producing smooth yet realistic representations ocean variables key areas interest. method especially effective regions sufficient data coverage can resolve mesoscale processes critical local downscaled models.specific case hydrodynamics, coastal models designed resolve local hydrological conditions rely nested within larger regional models order capture broader oceanographic influences drive local dynamics. However, whilst nesting hydrodynamic models common practice, specifying regional biogeochemical conditions coastal biogeochemical models presents greater challenge (Fukumori et al., 2018). difficulty arises primarily lack readily available regional biogeochemical models able capture coastally relevant features, scarcity observational data ocean model boundaries. Another significant issue many climatology studies high degree inhomogeneity ocean observations time. process filling spatial temporal gaps records often depends statistical assumptions , sometimes plausible, generally untestable (Boyer et al., 2016; Wunsch, 2018). time developing CSIEM, best knowledge, extended-time ocean climatology specifically developed Western Australian coastal region, yet required enable development comprehensive water quality model.describe creation continuous, monthly-resolution ocean climatology Perth coastal waters region, focusing temperature, salinity, biogeochemical properties needed inform boundary conditions CSIEM platform associated analyses. expand concept regional ocean climatologies incorporating biogeochemical data along side predictions available regional hydrodynamic model. achieve , undertake synthesis combining regional resolution ROMS model, satellite imagery, available -situ data. resulting data product covers period 1980 2024, provides continuous key ocean water properties can used boundary condition specification localized models Perth’s coastal waters.

heading: 5.2 Oceanographic context of Perth Waters and Cockburn Sound
text: Cockburn Sound open bay situated southwestern Australian (SWA) coastal region Indian Ocean. Sound spans area approximately 80 km2 maximum depth 22m (Figure 3.1). bordered coastal line east south, Garden Island west, relatively shallow entrance north (transect Garden Island Woodman Point), depths generally less 5 meters, except narrow shipping channel 15m. geographical features give Sound ‘Mediterranean Sea’ effect, restricted flow southern entrance ocean exchange primarily occurring northern entrance. Anomalies sea level, temperature, salinity, biological activity originating broader Indian ocean can strongly influence properties SWA shelf (e.g. Gaughan Fletcher, 1997; Koslow et al., 2008; Rose et al., 2012).oceanography SWA coastal region characterized combination warm currents climate-driven changes shape marine ecosystems, affecting marine biodiversity coastal processes. region dominated Leeuwin Current, poleward-flowing, warm, nutrient-poor current. current promotes downwelling local upwelling along continental shelf, creates unique marine environment supports warm- cool-water species (Smith et al., 1991; James et al., 1999).Climatic variations, including shifts winter rainfall patterns, closely tied broader atmospheric oceanic circulation systems. Research indicates fluctuations long-term mean sea-level pressure Perth negatively correlated austral winter rainfall, trending downward recent decades, affecting freshwater input coastal dynamics (Allan & Haylock, 1993; Silberstein et al., 2012; Smith & Power, 2014). SWA coastal region also influenced strong northward winds particularly austral summer. sea breezes featured diurnal pattern, rotating anticlockwise direction translating coastal currents, particularly along shoreline within coastal embayment (Pattiaratchi et al., 1999; Gallop et al., 2012). Marine heatwaves, significant event 2011, highlight vulnerability region's ecosystems lead widespread coral bleaching, fish die-offs, harmful algal blooms (Rose et al., 2012).

heading: 5.3 Analysis approach
text:
conventional method constructing ocean climatology generally involves two stages. first stage latitude-longitude-depth averaging selected scales, followed interpolation sparse-grid datasets high-resolution climatology (Lozano et al., 1996; Kim et al., 2007). first stage entails collection available datasets within area interest rigorous data screening. second stage involves remapping data onto space using multivariate statistical exercise known multi-scale objective analysis. approach widely used, typically applied large domains spatial scales degrees longitude latitude, often yielding spatial resolution 10-100km. Moreover, climatology products limited temperature including salinity (e.g. Kim et al., 2007; Fukumori et al., 2018).aim project component construct climatology hydrologic ecologic properties CSIEM boundary. spatial scale study much smaller compared conventional ocean climatology, resolving nutrient plankton climatology presents additional challenges. heading: 5.4.2 Boundary climatology – water temperature and salinity
text: ROMS model outputs Theme 5.1 WA region used provide hydrographic boundary conditions CSIEM. outputs include tidal elevations, water temperature, salinity, ocean currents three-hourly intervals. Example snapshots ROMS surface water temperature comparison GHRSST products (Figure 5.3) showed ROMS GHRSST datasets present similar spatial temperature patterns higher temperatures concentrated northern region decreased towards south. ROMS model exhibits slightly uniform temperature gradients compared GHRSST displays localized high-temperature zones, especially around coastal areas. Similar plots comparing ROMS salinity MOI data (Figure 5.5) suggest ROMS MOI salinity distributions agree broader spatial salinity trends, slight increase salinity north south. However, ROMS model provides smoothed representation, whereas MOI data reveals finer coastal salinity variations, indicating possible differences resolution ability capture localized coastal salinity features.Figure 5.4. heading: 6.2 Hydrodynamic setting
text: brief, purposes contextualising model approach, primary driver circulation Cockburn Sound wind, particularly prevailing south-westerly sea breeze summer months. consistent wind pattern induces two-layer circulation surface waters driven northward wind, compensatory return flow develops depth, moving southward. mechanism critical transporting heat, nutrients, properties throughout water column across basin. horizontal shear established flows generally effective promoting vertical mixing, however, periods sustained solar heating calm weather, thermal stratification intensifies, vertical mixing becomes inhibited.pattern stratification typically develops late spring can persist summer early autumn. Solar heating surface, combined weak tidal mixing reduced wind-driven turbulence, results formation pycnocline separating bottom waters, notable southern region Sound, residence time bottom water longest flushing restricted. contrast, winter months, increased storm activity shift variable northerly winds enhance vertical mixing, eroding stratification replenishing oxygen levels throughout water column. Freshwater inputs surface runoff groundwater limited Cockburn Sound, thus salinity-driven stratification generally weak. However, certain conditions, especially following large rainfall events proximity anthropogenic discharges, salinity gradients can form contribute stratification, albeit lesser extent thermal effects. addition natural dynamics, hypersaline discharges Perth Seawater Desalination Plant potential intensify near-bottom density stratification (BMT 2019). discharges tend move along seabed due higher salinity, can exacerbate hypoxic conditions overlaid stable, warmer water column. Warm waters discharged cooling industrial facilities can also contributed vertical buoyancy gradients along Kwinana Shelf.Tidal forcing plays relatively minor role overall circulation Cockburn Sound. microtidal regime, tidal ranges averaging around 0.5 metres, results weak tidal currents generally insufficient drive substantial mixing water exchange . Nonetheless, tides contribute localized nearshore residual circulation features can influence sediment resuspension mixing near coastal infrastructure, particularly combination wind forcing.embayment’s capacity flushing water renewal varies spatially seasonally. northern part Cockburn Sound, connections offshore waters direct wind-induced circulation stronger, flushing times relatively short—order several days favourable wind conditions. contrast, southern basin experiences significantly longer residence times, often exceeding 30 50 days summer. notable modification natural hydrodynamic regime construction Garden Island Causeway 1970s, connects mainland Garden Island. solid structure substantially impedes natural exchange water central basin offshore waters, particularly vicinity causeway. result, regions south Cockburn Sound exhibit extended residence times greater susceptibility water quality deterioration.Ability resolve flushing times, key circulation features effect stratification, important resolve due role shaping accumulation patterns nutrients, reduced oxygen concentrations, water quality processes like algal bloom development. Early three-dimensional models (e.g. Mills D’Adamo, 1995) provided key insights seasonal circulation patterns effects infrastructure like Garden Island Causeway. recently, range high-resolution models (e.g., FVCOM, TUFLOW-FV, SCHISM, ROMS, ELCOM) applied various applications demonstrate good performance simulate hydrodynamics Sound, including two-layer wind-driven circulation, residual currents temperature structure (e.g., Xiao et al., 2022).additional requirement integrated prediction EIA sound flexibility capturing role coastal infrastructure associated. Desalination operations, port development, dredging activities impact hydrodynamic sediment movement. particular, dredging port operations also modify local bathymetry time, modifying currents remobilising sediments.section, model setup described previous chapters tested available data waves, currents, water level, temperature salinity.
